image.altText: Shyanne-Lee Tatnell CCTV thumb

items.synopsis: Tasmania Police have released CCTV footage showing the last known movements of teenager Shyanne-Lee Tatnell, who has now been missing for two months. They have also narrowed down the vehicles of interest to just one.

title.children: Police release CCTV of missing Tasmanian teen, continue search for mystery car

image.altText: View over Hobart suburbs to Dynyrrne and Southern Outlet, June 2023

items.synopsis: A report by the Tenants Union of Tasmania has found despite popular belief, most short-stay properties are owned by Tasmanians, not international investors and the average owner has a property portfolio worth much more than average household wealth.

title.children: Who owns short-stay accommodation in Australia's short-stay capital?

image.altText: SES searchers and Celine Cremer

items.synopsis: As the search for missing Belgian woman Celine Cremer nears the end of its fourth day, police release vision showing the hostile conditions teams face as hopes fade for her to be found alive.

title.children: Hopes fade for missing Belgian tourist, as Tasmanian SES teams battle harsh terrain

image.altText: An aerial view of Ashley Youth Detention Centre.

items.synopsis: A former detainee at Ashley Youth Detention Centre claims staff turned off fire sprinklers, leading him to suffer burns and smoke inhalation.

title.children: Former youth detainee says staff turned off fire sprinklers

image.altText: Wind turbines on a hill.

items.synopsis: Some households are facing power price hikes of up to 100 per cent as the "long tail" of last year's energy crisis hits home hard, according to consumer advocates.

title.children: Power prices to skyrocket in eastern states as energy chaos fallout hits hard

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian and Daryl Maguire.

items.synopsis: Hear the intimate phone calls — some of which have never been heard publicly before — at the heart of ICAC's inquiry into the former premier of NSW.

title.children: What the intercepted Berejiklian-Maguire calls reveal

image.altText: composite images of Daryl Maguire and a bag and wads of cash spread out on a table.

items.synopsis: The Independent Commission Against Corruption has uncovered much more than former MP Daryl Maguire's secret relationship with then-premier Gladys Berejiklian.

title.children: 'Cash for visas': How ICAC discovered Daryl Maguire was a 'door opener' for property developers and Chinese nationals

image.altText: A woman with dark hair stands, arms crossed, against a wall in a kitchen with pots and pans behind her

items.synopsis: Last year, a cap on the hours international students could work was lifted to help counter COVID workforce shortages. It's being reinstated from July — and employers and students are worried.

title.children: Limits on the amount of hours international students can work are set to return — and employers are nervous

image.altText: Passengers at Sydney Airport

items.synopsis: Almost 50 domestic flights are cancelled across the major airlines including Qantas, Virgin and Jetstar with the airport restricted to one runway.

title.children: Passengers stranded as dozens of flights cancelled at Sydney Airport due to strong winds

image.altText: Vladimir Putin and Sergei Shoigu wear hats but no shirts as they lounge on a lakeside dock.

items.synopsis: Sergei Shoigu, Vladimir Putin's longtime defence minister and close confidant, has so far held onto his position and survived an all-out mutiny staged by one of his most powerful opponents.

title.children: 'There's no one else like him in the ruling class': The surprising rise of Putin's closest friend

image.altText: A woman smiles and holds up four Taylor Swift records in front of her.

items.synopsis: When Bridget Saric sat down at her computer before sunrise on Wednesday, all the preparations for battle were in place. It wasn't enough to land her pre-sale Taylor Swift tickets.

title.children: Four million people lined up for pre-sale Taylor Swift tickets. This is what it was like

image.altText: Blond woman in sparkly top points at camera against purple backdrop

items.synopsis: The Victorian government says they're on high alert for dodgy scammers selling tickets to Taylor Swift's Eras Tour but there are other ways fans can protect themselves.

title.children: Didn't manage to get Taylor Swift tickets? Here's how to avoid getting scammed on the resale

image.altText: A man in a blue suit walks hand in hand with a woman in a wedding dress whose face has been blurred for privacy.

items.synopsis: Homicide investigators ask for information from the public as they examine the death of 37-year-old Matthew Berry on the Gold Coast hinterland.

title.children: Police appeal after father-of-two identified as homicide victim

items.synopsis: Minister for Indigenous Australians Linda Burney said the Voice would not recommend moving or abolishing Australia Day. But is there anything in the proposal to stop it from doing so?

title.children: Fact checking Linda Burney's claim that the Voice would not offer advice on moving Australia Day

image.altText: A woman in a white gown stands smiling holding flowers, a close up photo of a man is next in a separate photo

items.synopsis: Craig Rumsby is found guilty of murdering 17-year-old Michelle Bright at Gulgong in the Central West of New South Wales in 1999.

title.children: Michelle Bright, 17, was murdered in 1999. Today a jury found Craig Rumsby guilty of killing her and dumping her body

image.altText: Erin

items.synopsis: Experts warn a culture of disbelief in Australia's family court system is resulting in children being sent to live with their alleged abusers, leaving them with lifelong consequences.

title.children: Erin told a family court report writer her father abused her. She was then forced to live with him full time

image.altText: An artist’s composition of the Milky Way seen through a blue lens.

items.synopsis: In a world-first, scientists say they produced an image of the Milky Way not based on electromagnetic radiation — light — but on ghostly subatomic particles called neutrinos.

title.children: Scientists see 'ghost' particles originating from the Milky Way for the first time

image.altText: An older man with dark hair and thick rimmed square glasses waring a suit and tie looks ahead in front of Qantas logos.

items.synopsis: Outgoing Qantas chief Alan Joyce says crime is to blame for a drop in flights and hike in flight prices to Alice Springs.

title.children: Qantas chief says Alice Springs' tourism groups need to do more as visitation drops

image.altText: An elderly woman with glasses smiling with a flower border. An elderly man with glasses smiling.

items.synopsis: Brenda and Lynton Anderson died a year apart, both aged 94. Now police have declared a major crime investigation into their deaths, suspecting the couple may have been murdered by the same person. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: Police believe an elderly South Australian couple were murdered. Here's what we know so far

image.altText: Nathan Lyon looks upset as he sits with a team doctor outside the boundary rope

items.synopsis: England's response to Australia's short-pitched bowling brings the second Test at Lord's to life, but it's Nathan Lyon's calf injury that could yet have the biggest say in this Ashes series, writes Dean Bilton.

title.children: As an injured and emotional Lyon left Lord's, Australia was forced into an unexpected backup plan

image.altText: A man in spectacles and a backwards cap shares a laugh with a teammate.

items.synopsis: As Australia nervously waits for news on Nathan Lyon's calf injury, key figures have thrown their support behind back-up spinner Todd Murphy.

title.children: 'It's a big loss for us': Australia facing a 10-year first as injury puts Ashes plans in a spin

image.altText: Power lines at sunrise in the Perth suburb of Treeby.

items.synopsis: The ASX opens unexpectedly lower on the last day of the 2022-23 financial year after the Australian Energy Regulator charges AGL for failing to meet its obligations under the National Electricity Rules. Follow live.

title.children: AGL charged by energy regulator for breaching electricity rules, ASX opens lower on final day of financial year

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Link Administration is shaping up to be the worst performer on the market today — so far it's plummeted 13.4%, and there's around an hour and a half of trading left for the day. So what's caused it? It's all because of superannuation giant HESTA not renewing their contract with the business. Link has provided administration services to the super fund under a nine-year contract, but HESTA won't renew the contract once the current one runs out and will transition out by the second quarter of the 2025 financial year. HESTA makes up around 4% of Link's estimated group revenue for FY23, but Link says its guidance for its operating earnings before interest and taxes will be "slightly above the upper end of the 10-12% guidance range". Moving forward, HESTA will partner with Grow Inc for its administration services.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's behind the falling Link Administration share price?

children.content: Link Administration is shaping up to be the worst performer on the market today — so far it's plummeted 13.4%, and there's around an hour and a half of trading left for the day.
So what's caused it? It's all because of superannuation giant HESTA not renewing their contract with the business.

Link has provided administration services to the super fund under a nine-year contract, but HESTA won't renew the contract once the current one runs out and will transition out by the second quarter of the 2025 financial year.

HESTA makes up around 4% of Link's estimated group revenue for FY23, but Link says its guidance for its operating earnings before interest and taxes will be "slightly above the upper end of the 10-12% guidance range".
Moving forward, HESTA will partner with Grow Inc for its administration services.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX is more or less in a holding pattern as we head into the second half of the trading day, down by 0.2% to 7,183 points. The sectors are fairly mixed too, with real estate and industrials down the most (0.5% each), while utilities and energy are the strongest performers, up 0.5% each. But when we look at the top and bottom movers, things get a little more interesting. The top five gains so far have been: Imugene +8.4% Downer EDI +3.4% NRW Holdings -2.8% De Grey Mining +2.7% Star Entertainment Group +2.7% At the other end of the scale, those with the biggest losses: Link Administration Holdings -12.6% Abacus Property Group -4% Lake Resources -2.5% Inghams -2.3% Bega Cheese -2.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX down slightly as Link shares fall by 12.6pc

children.content: The ASX is more or less in a holding pattern as we head into the second half of the trading day, down by 0.2% to 7,183 points.
The sectors are fairly mixed too, with real estate and industrials down the most (0.5% each), while utilities and energy are the strongest performers, up 0.5% each.
But when we look at the top and bottom movers, things get a little more interesting.
The top five gains so far have been:
Imugene +8.4%
Downer EDI +3.4%
NRW Holdings -2.8%
De Grey Mining +2.7%
Star Entertainment Group +2.7%
At the other end of the scale, those with the biggest losses:
Link Administration Holdings -12.6%
Abacus Property Group -4%
Lake Resources -2.5%
Inghams -2.3%
Bega Cheese -2.1%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you can believe it, tomorrow is July 1 — and there's a whole lot of new changes coming into effect from the start of the new financial year. The biggest change is that the minimum wage will go up for thousands of workers by 8.6%, with the new hourly rate of $23.23, and $882.80 per week (based on a 38-hour week). Award workers will also see a 5.75% increase. The super guarantee is also rising from tomorrow, increasing by 0.5% to 11%. There's plenty more changes happening from tomorrow, which have been summarised in the story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Minimum wage increase comes into effect from tomorrow

featuredLink.title: From superannuation to working from home — these are the July 1 financial changes

children.content: If you can believe it, tomorrow is July 1 — and there's a whole lot of new changes coming into effect from the start of the new financial year.
The biggest change is that the
minimum wage will go up for thousands of workers by 8.6%
, with the new hourly rate of $23.23, and $882.80 per week (based on a 38-hour week).
Award workers will also see a 5.75% increase.
The super guarantee is also rising from tomorrow, increasing by 0.5% to 11%.
There's plenty more changes happening from tomorrow, which have been summarised in the story below:

image.altText: A map of Victoria showing an earthquake epicentre

items.synopsis: Thousands of people report feeling the effects of an early morning earthquake in Victoria's High Country, which seismologists say may be a part of a sequence that began in 2021.

title.children: Tremors felt in Melbourne as magnitude-4.6 earthquake strikes Victoria

image.altText: NAIDOC Week Finalists: Donnell Wallam, Aaron Fa'aoso and Rachel Perkins

items.synopsis: From a pool of almost 200 nominees, meet this year's 2023 National NAIDOC Week Award finalists.

title.children: Almost 200 nominees, but who made the cut for the 2023 NAIDOC Week Awards?

image.altText: Elliot Yeo

items.synopsis: It was one of the biggest losses in AFL history — so how did the Swans do it, and what's next for the struggling Eagles? Cody Atkinson and Sean Lawson explain.

title.children: Anatomy of a demolition — how the Swans picked apart the Eagles to create AFL history

image.altText: Taylor swift in a gold body suit singing into a microphone with a male dancer behind her

items.synopsis: Four million Australians tried to get tickets to Taylor Swift on Wednesday's pre-sale, with millions more expected to log on today.

title.children: Planning on trying to buy tickets to Taylor Swift's Eras tour today? Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Close up of a sign advertising a house for sale in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: An increasing number of Australians are selling homes that they have owned for fewer than two years, many at a loss, and analysts warn it might be an early sign of mortgage distress.

title.children: 'Calmly selling': Are struggling mortgage borrowers starting to get out while the going is still good?

image.altText: Gloved hand holding genetic test tube

items.synopsis: Life insurance companies are accused of "genetic discrimination" in determining coverage and premiums, with researchers finding some Australians are skipping tests that could detect risk of disease to avoid the results affecting their life insurance.

title.children: Australians skipping genetic screening tests out of fear it will affect life insurance coverage

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian.

items.synopsis: The significance of the findings against Gladys Berejiklian shouldn’t be lost, even if the fallout and political impacts appear minimal.

title.children: What lessons can be learnt from the Gladys Berejiklian corruption investigation?

image.altText: Smoke is seen around a deflated balloon against a clear blue sky

items.synopsis: A suspected Chinese spy balloon that flew over the United States earlier this year before being shot down did not collect information as it went across the country, the Pentagon has said.

title.children: Suspected Chinese spy balloon did not collect intelligence over United States, Pentagon says

items.synopsis: The flight marked a long-delayed breakthrough for the company after 20 years of development setbacks.

title.children: Branson's rocket plane takes its first paying passengers to the edge of space

image.altText: Japanese and Australian navies conduct joint exercises

items.synopsis: An Australian warship and surveillance aircraft have conducted military exercises with Japan in the South China Sea under the close watch of the People's Liberation Army.

title.children: Australia and Japan conduct war games in contested waters as China watches closely

image.altText: Scot Peterson clasping his hands together, weeping, as the verdict is read aloud in court.

items.synopsis: A former Florida sheriff's deputy has been found not guilty of failing to protect students during the 2018 Parkland school shooting.

title.children: Deputy acquitted of all charges for failing to act during deadly Parkland school shooting

image.altText: A graphic illustration of July on calendar

items.synopsis: From July 1, Australians are looking at a raft of financial changes. Here's a breakdown of each change happening from July 1.

title.children: From superannuation to working from home — these are the July 1 financial changes

image.altText: A woman in green and gold football gear shouts instructions to her teammates.

items.synopsis: Wallaroos stand-in skipper Michaela Leonard apologises to fans as New Zealand thumps the Australians 50-0.

title.children: Wallaroos skipper apologises to fans after Australia trounced 50-0 by New Zealand in Pacific Four opener
